name: Yellow Mongoose
description: It earned its name from its bushy tail and summer coat, which is short and reddish. In winter, it moults into a longer, denser, and lighter tawny coat.
spread_note: Southern Africa – Namibia, Botswana, Natal, Transvaal, Zimbabwe, Cape Province
food_note: Small animals, primarily insects, but also other invertebrates and smaller vertebrates (rodents, lizards)
image_alt: Yellow Mongoose, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 25–40 cm; tail length 18–30 cm; weight 0.5–0.8 kg
reproduction: Females give birth to usually 2–3 young after a gestation of 60–62 days
attractions: Yellow mongooses are active during the day, tirelessly foraging or basking in the sun. Although they hunt individually, they are social and regroup with others in a shared burrow at night. They often occupy burrows of Cape ground squirrels, providing them with greater safety in return, as they frequently stand upright like meerkats, vigilantly scanning their surroundings.
breeding: The first yellow mongooses arrived in 2002 (the male still lives at the zoo), with more following in 2004 in connection with the completion of the reconstruction of the former small animal pavilion into the Africa Up Close pavilion.
